text: Dim, high-ceilinged. Gutted of half its pews. Broken stained glass windows. Vandalized statues of saints. Iconoclastic clutter lies beneath rusted, wrought iron st of votive candles. At the chapel's front: a decapitated Jesus hangs from a charred wooden cross above where an altar once stood. The altar space: converted to a computer work station. Pi of carelessly stashed discs and printouts abound. Sacristy doorways lead to kitchen and bathroom. An unmade brass bed sits off to one side. In an alcove off to the other side, a SHRINE. Candles bur in a votive stand. Framed pictures hang above it, their faces turned to the wall. A tormented FIGURE sits at the computer... Meet: QOHEN LETH, 40s, gaunt, pale and completely hairles His hands clench and unclench above his keyboard as he st mesmerized at the swirling image of a BLACK HOLE SCREENSA His rotary phone RINGS. Qohen blinks out of his trance, a look of panic on his fa and reaches for the phone... too late. The phone stops ringing before he can answer it. Qohen MOANS softly and turns back to his computer. He tap key and the screensaver disappears, replaced by a scrolli flurry of esoteric symbols. He types frenetically, eyes focused intensely. The phone RINGS. Qohen snatches the receiver.

Hello? Hello? No answer. Qohen SIGHS, slowly hangs up the receiver, and returns hi attention to the computer screen. He begins typing again.  His wind-up clock RINGS. Its hands read 5:09. Qohen jumps. He slaps the alarm off, rubs his eyes as if he's just awakened. Standing and stretching, he raises hi eyes to the disfigured crucifix before him.

Qohen stands in his small galley kitchen, waiting for the microwave to finish, an open container of generic "INSTAN OATMEAL" on the counter in front of him. An open cupboard above reveals various food products, all bland, all tasteless, all generically packaged in white w block black lettering. Qohen methodically sets the counter with plate, napkin, spoon... and, after retrieving the spoon from its drawer, notices a steak knife. He picks it up, studies its edge, then... gently traces a forearm vein, like an architect drawing a blueprint. The knife draws blood. Qohen stares at it. The microwave BEEPS. The wall phone RINGS. Qohen looks confused for a moment. Then, frantic and hopeful, he lunges for the phone.
Hello? He listens, face turning bland.

No... We're sorry... We're afraid you have the wrong number. Qohen hangs up, takes his steaming bowl of oatmeal from t microwave. He stands at the counter, spoon in hand, stari at the bowl with slight distaste: just another job to do. He absently brings his wrist to his mouth, tastes the blo His face sours. He grabs his napkin and wipes his tongue clean.
Qohen stares at himself in the mirror as he brushes his teeth. He spits, takes a deep breath.
Clad in black, sleeves and collar buttoned, Qohen pops a out of his computer and slips it into his shirt pocket.
Qohen lights a candle. He stares at one of the picture frames, then carefully turns it to reveal its hidden phot

Standing on the front porch of a suburban home, Qohen's W holds their baby SON in her arms, both smiling at the cam She holds the baby's hand up in a pudgy-fingered wave. Standing behind the two, YOUNG QOHEN beams with pride.
Qohen gazes at the photo, then bows his head, fighting hi emotion. He turns the picture's face to the wall again. He walks down the long aisle to the chapel door, opens it
Qohen approaches a great oak door. He hesitates as he touches the doorknob, bracing himself, then opens it... -..to a blast of light and STREET NOISES.

Qohen exits. Colorful graffiti mars words etched in stone above the door: "THE BROTHERHOOD OF THE INEFFABLE NAME". He hurries past caged storefronts, eyes downcast. Near his bus stop, Qohen sees a GIRL, 10, sitting on the beside a toppled bicycle. She holds a skinned knee, CRYIN Qohen hesitates, looks around. No one else is there to he He approaches the Girl cautiously.

We hate to impose ourselves, but... may we assist you in any way? The Girl covers her face with her hands, still CRYING. Qohen stares at her helplessly, then moves to her bike. A bent fender scrapes the front wheel when he tests it. tries to pry the fender back into shape. The Girl drops her hands from her face.
Leave my bike alone! Leave it alone! A SIREN sounds close by, and a helmeted MOTORCYCLE COP sk up to the curb, engine ROARING. He turns off the siren, dismounts, slowly approaches Qohen and the girl.
Please step back from the child, sir.
We were simply attempting to --

Put down the bike and step back. Qohen gently lays down the bicycle. His bus passes, and he hastens to his stop. The bus door opens. Qohen looks at the Motorcycle Cop comforting the crying Girl. His face tightens.
Qohen sits alone in the rear seat. The bus jumps and jostles. Qohen shuts his eyes, hands folded as if in pray TRAFFIC NOISES BLARE in a crescendo of anxiety.

Neat and orderly. No sign of personal belongings. One poster adorns the wall: a man's torso in a sharply- tailored taupe suit. Bold letters proclaim: "MANAGEMENT". Smaller script reads: "Everything's Under Control." A video camera (labeled MANCAM) records Qohen's every mov Except Qohen doesn't move. He simply sits staring at his computer monitor, trancelike. The image on the monitor shows Qohen from behind, staring an image of himself on his monitor staring at an image of himself... ad infinitum. His phone RINGS. Qohen slowly comes back to reality as the phone continues RINGING. Finally, he picks up the receiver.  A female COMPUTERIZED VOICE speaks.
Hello -- Qohen Leth -- Corporate Health Maintenance has approved review of your disability request for today at 14:40. Please be prompt.

We are nothing if not prompt. Qohen hangs up, glances at his watch. He touches his keyboard: the image of himself shrinks to the screen's up corner, replaced by a column of flashing signs, cryptic symbols, formulae and numerals. Qohen frowns and with some effort begins typing. MR. JOBY, 20s, appears in the cubicle's doorway, scratchi an elusive itch inside his ill-fitting suit coat. He is a soft, manic-looking man with shaggy hair and beard.
How's it hanging, Quinn?
(without looking up) It's Qohen, Mr. Joby, and, as we've told you before, it isn't hanging at all well. We're dying.
Again? Better see the medics about that.
We have an appointment this afternoon.
Not this afternoon, Quinn.
You approved it.
Cancel it. You got that Transfinite Quantum Paradox Project due today.
We attached it to you yesterday.
Good work. But you still have that Whatchacallit Project due next week.
The Neural Synaptic Intervention Project. Also finished. (MORE )
Tautologics Division is running the standard redundancies.
Whoa! You did all that this morning?

We did it all at home last night. As we've told you repeatedly, we find our work environment... distressing. The people, the lighting, the noise, the interruptions, the... the people... (taking a deep breath) Considering our at-home output, we can't begin to imagine why you insist on our coming here each day. Joby removes his suit coat and reaches over his shoulder pursue a particularly shy itch.
That's a Management decision, Quinn.
Qohen. Q--no U--O-H-E-N.
Out of my hands.
Perhaps we should talk to Management. Joby stifles a guffaw, then casually drapes his suit over the ManCam.
(voice lowered) Nobody talks to Management, Quinn. No way, no how, nuh-uh, nyetskis. Take my advice. Knock off the bitching and moaning. It's not all that bad here.
It's worse than you can imagine, Mr. Joby, but we could suffer the wear and tear on our nerves if only we weren't afraid of missing our call.
Your call...
Yes, our call. We've mentioned it a number of times.
.»-. Ain't ringing a bell. coat
We're expecting a certain phone call, a call we've been waiting for all our lives, a call that will give our lives purpose and meaning, and each minute we spend here, we fear we may be missing it.
Oh. Right. That call. Um... How about letting your machine take it? Or get call forwarding. I guess I could bend the rules on personal calls in your case.
We have to be home to receive it. Joby shakes his head, stumped. He moves behind Qohen and massages his shoulders.
I feel for you, Quinn, but there's nothing I can do.
(stiffening) We prefer not to be touched. Joby stops, steps back.
We've been extremely patient, Mr. Joby, but we're afraid we must now issue an ultimatum. Either you let us work at home, or we will be forced to resign.
You can't quit, Quinn! You're the best cruncher I got! Qohen turns back to his computer and resumes typing.
If our meeting with Health Maintenance is successful, the issue will be settled. If not, you leave us no choice.
You're killing me! Be reasonable! Qohen ignores him. Joby grabs his coat and turns to leave, frustrated.
I'll see what I can do, Quinn.

Three doctors sit at one end of a long table, grayish lig from an overcast day sifting through the window behind th At the head sits DOCTOR #1, a prim woman in a drab busine suit. She polishes her bifocals with a tissue. To her right sits DOCTOR #2, a middle-aged man in hospita scrubs that reveal a NicoDerm patch on his upper arm. He chews a wad of Nicorette gum while perusing Qohen's file. DOCTOR #3 slouches to Doctor #1's left. A handsome young in a white lab coat, stethoscope draped around his neck, gazes out the window with the soulful look of a bored poe Qohen sits stone-faced at the far end of the table. Doctor #1 puts on her glasses to appraise him.
And this is...? Doctor #2 nervously clicks his pen, chomping on his gum.
Qohen Leth, Ontological Research Division, requesting Disability Leave.
Or reassignment to work at home.
That's a Management decision, Mr. Leth. We only deal with health issues here. What seems to be the problem?
We're dying.
Who's "we"?
Us. Ourselves.
But there's only the one of you.
So it would appear. Doctor #3 SNIFFS, returns to gazing out the window.
(consulting file) Subject's had five physicals in the last year. He's healthy as a horse. Doctor #1 takes the file from him, scanning it.
What makes you think you're dying?
We can feel it. Deep inside us...
Heart's strong as an ox. (a frustrated puff on pen) BP and cholesterol I could only dream of.
Our hair has fallen out.
Idiopathic.
Perfectly harmless. The tests don't lie.
Then the tests are merely mistaken.
According to your file, you're the most productive number cruncher in your --
Entity cruncher. Our data is much more complex than mere numbers.
Dying people are rarely so productive.
Nevertheless, we're dying.
No you're not.
Yes we are.
No you're not!

Yes we are.  10. Doctor #2 grabs the Nicorette pack, savagely rips loose a piece of gum and shoves it in his mouth. Doctor #3, supremely bored now, uses his stethoscope to listen to his own heartbeat.
Perhaps we should get another opinion.
Oh, let me do this one! Please? Doctor #1 nods. Doctor #3 sits up, clears his throat.
From the moment we're born, we all begin to die. Sooner or later, beggar or king, death comes to all.
That will do, Doctor.
But it's true.
Where'd you get your degree?
Disability request denied. It's back to work for you, Mr. Leth. Qohen rises to leave, defeated. Doctor #1 takes off her glasses, studying him.
This board must also recommend that you seek psychiatric evaluation. Doctor #2 waves a CD-ROM.
I saw this coming a mile away.
We've seen psychiatrists in the past. It's proven to be a waste of our time. We must stay home to wait for our call.
You'll have time for this one. He slides the CD-ROM down the table. Qohen picks it up. T cover reads: DR. SHRINK-ROM: INTERACTIVE PSYCHIATRIST.
She makes house calls.  11.
Joby stands in Qohen's doorway, arms folded.
Didn't figure the medics would help, but Joby's here. I can get Management to see you. He'll be at my party tonight.
Party?
(sheepishly) Guess you missed your invitation. Whole office is coming, including Management himself. Just show up. I'll take care of the rest.
We're afraid we can't.
What, gotta stay home and shampoo? Joby playfully musses Qohen's hairless head but, seeing h frigid expression, quickly stops.
We fear parties... We especially fear living rooms at parties... We never know quite... where to stand. Joby stares, then suddenly LAUGHS, slapping him on the ba
You kill me, Quinn. See you tonight. Joby leaves. Qohen takes a deep breath to calm himself.
It's Qohen.
Qohen uncomfortably plods his way through a room crowded CO-WORKERS. He is lost amid the LAUGHTER AND CONVERSATION He passes a couple of CO-WORKERS who eye him derisively.
Who's the geeky goth?

Cube zombie. Some kind of Einstein.  12. Qohen bumps into BAINSLEY, 20s, wearing a loudly-patterne dress her buxom figure seems to be bursting out of. Qohen steps to his right just as Bainsley steps to her le She steps to her left just as Qohen shifts to his right. Bainsley GIGGLES, still blocking his way.

I love the look. Fifty-first century human, the final evolutionary product. Maximum brain, minimalist body. Qohen stares at her, then clumsily makes his way past her Qohen finds Joby, obviously tipsy, laughing with a crowd.
Party boy! You made it!
Is Management here? The group looks at Qohen strangely. Joby LAUGHS uncomfortably, takes Qohen's arm, and moves him away.
(whispering) You wanna start a rumor riot?
Where is Management?
Probably on his way. Soon as I spot him, I'll let you know. Meantime... Joby slaps Qohen on the back. Qohen flinches.
(loudly) Lighten up, have a little fun for a change. Mingle, Quinn, mingle!
It's Qohen.
Of course it is. Joby gives Qohen a push on his way. As Qohen looks for a place to retreat from the party crus NOISES FADE. He enters a quiet corner of the room.  13.

Two wing-back chairs flank a table with a reading lamp. In the furthest chair sits MANAGEMENT, dressed in the sam taupe suit featured in the poster in Qohen's office, a su that, chameleon-like, matches the color of the chair. He blends in so well that, at first, Qohen doesn't even see But when he does, Qohen stops, takes a step back. Management holds a book at eye level. With his other hand he balances a teacup and saucer on his knee. Apparently engrossed in his reading, Management lifts the teacup, ta a delicate sip, and returns the cup carefully to its sauc Qohen quietly turns to leave.
I take it you're not happy, Mr. Leth. Qohen hesitates, startled.
Do we... know you? Still not looking at Qohen, Management turns a page.
I know you, Mr. Leth. Sit. Qohen grimaces in the direction of the party, then nervou perches on the edge of the empty chair. Management sips from his teacup, eyes riveted on the page
What seems to be the problem?
We... We simply want to go home. Qohen notices Management's bland disinterest.
We could easily double our output there. Management turns another page. Qohen drums his fingers on his knees.
Our chief concern is that we might miss our call... You see, we have been waiting for a certain call all our lives now...  14. Management stops reading, slowly looks up from his book.

.+-and although the nature and origin of our call remain quintessentially a mystery to us, we can't help but hope it will provide us with a purpose we've long lived without. Management studies Qohen for a moment, then blinks and returns his attention to his book.
You're quite insane, Mr. Leth. Qohen stands, cowed by Management's bland disinterest.
We're sorry to have disturbed you. He turns and flees to the...
Bainsley hovers over a tray of hors d'oeuvres, stuffing h face. She spies Qohen making for the door. Suddenly a drunken Joby snags Qohen.
Quinn, you chrome-domed bastard! Where are you going? Have a drink! Eat!
We saw him.
Who?
Management. People nearby overhear and turn to stare quizzically. Job makes a show of LAUGHING skeptically.
Better watch the cocktails, Quinn! (pulling him aside, whispering) Are you crazy? Management parties incognito!
This isn't working, Mr. Joby.
No shit! You're blowing his cover!  15.
We're afraid we must go now.
Wait. I'll get you a meeting with him. Joby steers Qohen to the buffet table.
You're not leaving without eating, Quinn!
It's Qohen. We've apparently had our meeting. And our diet dictates against all foods with perceptible flavor.
Eat. That's an order. Qohen surveys the food tray grimly. He SIGHS, selects an olive, and tucks it into his mouth, frowning.
(loudly) Plenty of eats! Joby slaps Qohen on the back. Qohen GULPS, lodging the olive deep in his throat.
Plenty more! Plenty for everybody! Joby moves off, drunkenly glad-handing other guests. Qohen stumbles away, struggling for breath.
Away from the crowd, Qohen falls against the wall, panic- stricken. He pounds his chest, trying to free the olive. He lurches to an open doorway.
As if by magic, Management sits behind a mahogany desk reading his book and sipping his tea. His eyes move from book to Qohen with an expression of mild amusement.
What is the meaning of life, Mr. Leth? Qohen clutches his throat, eyes bulging.  16.
So close to its end, and still no answer. Management closes his book.
I have a special project for you that might prove to be mutually beneficial. The room blurs.
But there's not much time, Mr. Leth. Not much time at all... Qohen's knees buckle... And then he is suddenly lifted off his feet from behind a dragged back into the...

Bainsley performs the Heimlich maneuver on Qohen. She los her balance, stumbles down the narrow corridor with him. hangs on fiercely, heaving him off his feet again and aga The olive SHOOTS from his mouth, ricochets off the wall a rolls to a stop by the baseboard. Instantly a scruffy rod appears, grabs the olive and disappears back into the wal Bainsley releases her hold. Qohen gasps for breath.
I thought I smelled trouble. The neckline of Bainsley's dress is tugged low. She blith plumps her breasts while rearranging her clothing.

Everybody hates to make a scene, but the worst thing you can do is go off by yourself. Embarrassment's the number one cause of choking deaths. Qohen stares into her eyes, speechless. He suddenly beeli for the bathroom. Closes the door. Locks it.

Qohen splashes water on his face. He stares at himself in the mirror. He reaches to touch his reflection... then staggers backward with a look of pain. He sits on the toilet seat, face buried in his hands. A loud KNOCK at the door. Qohen jumps to his feet, startl  17.
Still alive in there? Qohen quickly dries his face and opens the door. Bainsley squeezes past him, hands him her wine glass.
Hold this. She heads for the toilet, hiking her dress to the top of thighs. Qohen stares. Bainsley smiles...
Care to join me?
Excuse us?
(winking) Close the door... I won't be long.
Qohen closes the door and stands uncomfortably, wine in h He sniffs it distastefully, then eases to the study.
Qohen scans the room, puzzled. Management is gone.

Qohen stands obediently outside the bathroom door. The toilet FLUSHES. The faucet RUNS. The door opens. Bainsley exits, smoothing her dress. She flashes Qohen a sexy smile, takes the wine glass from him
So I saved your life. No big deal?
Forgive our ambivalence. Thank you.
You owe me. I'm Bainsley. She takes his hand in hers, looks him up and down.
And you are...?
Qohen. Q--no U--  18.
You work with these people?
In a manner of speaking.
What do you do?
We crunch entities.
You got a mouse in your pocket?
Excuse us?
Who's "we"?
Us. Ourselves.
Catchy. She tugs at her dress as if uncomfortable with its fit.
You're staring at me. You think my dress is incredibly ugly.
We -- we really should be going --

It's my daddy's fault. He used to buy me these incredibly ugly clothes to keep the boys away. Didn't work. Only made me want to get naked, and that's no way to keep the boys away. So I never developed a fashion sense. Are you on drugs?
No.
Have you tried them?
We have tried many pharmaceuticals, both therapeutic and recreational, but we've discovered none with sufficient potency to treat our essential condition.  She leans 19.
I hear you. You should try natural herbs. I'm happy with the herbs. Way happy. They should put St. John's Wort in the drinking water, like fluoride... close and rests an elbow on his shoulder.
...Are you here alone?
We are generally everywhere alone.
The "we" thing: royal or plural?
Generic. She trails her fingernails over the skin of his scalp.
Love it. You're the enigmatic workaholic technogeek. I'm the mysterious party- girl. My place or yours?
We'd only disappoint you.
Best line I've heard all night. Her lips move close to his. Qohen pulls back, flustered.
We can't imagine your interest in us.
I saved your life. That's a turn-on.
We really must be leaving. Bainsley touches a finger to his lips.
Seriously. We could have some fun. She caresses his chest, pulls a felt-tip pen from his poc and scrawls her name and number on the palm of his hand.
Call me. Qohen stares at his hand.  20.
Qohen scrubs his hand in scalding water. He looks at hims in the mirror. Steam obscures his reflection.

Gulls SCREECH. The surf CRASHES and ROARS. Young Qohen is buried in the sand up to his neck. His Wife tamps the sand down, LAUGHING, while his Son decorates the mound with seashells. Qohen struggles gamel to free himself, grinning with red-faced delight. Then his face goes slack, and he stares straight out at h inevitable future with a mixture of fear and revulsion...
Qohen studies the photo. He traces Young Qohen's smile wi his finger, then turns the picture's face to the wall.
Joby leads Qohen past a maze of cubicles. Sounds of TYPIN CONVERSATION, phones RINGING. Qohen hastens to keep up.
Be careful what you wish for, Quinn.
What's this all about?

You're going home. Management assigned you to the Zero Theorem Project. He's been hand-picking talent to crunch it since before I was hired. So far, no luck. The Clones are at your place right now setting up your hardware.
Clones?
Research and Development techies. They already changed the locks. Not to worry. You'll get a key. They reach a door labelled "MANCOM". Joby unlocks it.
I got my money on you, Quinn. Some big, bad entities to crunch, but I'm sure you'll be proving the theorem in no time.  21.
What exactly will we be proving?
Don't ask. It's all very hush-hush... Joby opens the door, releasing a cold fog.
A cavernous room filled with blinking banks of HUMMING, ceiling-high computers. Qohen can see his breath.
.+. But just between you and me... You solve Zip-T, I bet Management helps you get you that call of yours. Qohen stops -- surprised, hopeful.
He can do that? But how? Joby tugs Qohen's sleeve, pulls him forward.
Management works in mysterious ways, Quinn. As they walk down an aisle, a faint CLICKING grows louder

This is ManCom, biggest neural net computer in the world. Learns just like a human, trial and error, but a hell of a lot faster. Already the smartest thing on the planet... and still learning! They turn a corner. BOB, 15 -- frail, anemic, baggy-eyed -- sits at the contr console rapidly CLICKING a mouse. He's bundled in heavy jacket, hooded sweatshirt, scarf and fingerless gloves. A row of monitors flash dizzying images, a fast-changing encyclopedic array of charts, pictures, and geometric cod
Working hard, Bob?
(without looking up) Hardly working, Bob. Still teaching this stupid motherfucker... Excuse my French.  22.
Don't mind me. I'm just getting Quinn here started on Zip-T. Bob pulls off his hood to reveal a ratty pony tail. He gi Qohen a sideways glance.
I give him two weeks.
To complete the project?
(rolling eyes) Till you crash and burn, Bob. Joby pulls Qohen past Bob, turning another corner.
Who was that?
That was Bob.
But he called you Bob. He called us Bob.
Bob calls everybody Bob. Says it's a waste of brain cells remembering names. QOHEN ; Isn't he rather young to be working here?
Kid could program before he could walk. They reach a row of file cabinets. Joby opens a drawer, pulls out a stack of CD-ROMs, piles them into Qohen's han

Crunch this stuff for starters. Upload ASAP. ManCom will send you new downloads every day. Miss a deadline, you're off the project. How's that for pressure? Joby gives him more disks. Overwhelmed, Qohen struggles t keep from dropping them. Joby reaches into the drawer aga
Don't worry, Quinn. You got what you wanted. Everything's under control. Joby holds up the last disk, stares through its hole.  23.
You ever get the feeling the whole universe is a big fat cosmic joke... and maybe you're the punch line...? You ever get that feeling, Quinn?
It's Qohen. Joby tucks the final disk into Qohen's shirt pocket.
Uh-huh... That's what I figured.

Qohen ordering generic groceries from a website. 4. Qohen standing at his KITCHEN counter, eating a bland, joyless meal from a microwaveable container. 5. Qohen crunching entities. His new touch tone phone RINGS. He answers hopefully. He listens, hope dimming, th punches several buttons on the touch tone. 6. Monitor showing file upload in progress. 7. Qohen at his BATHROOM mirror rubbing baggy eyes. 8. Entities scrolling at breakneck speed on monitor, Qohe fingers flying on the keyboard, his expression grim. 9. Qohen lying awake in bed, tired eyes restless. 10. Qohen at the shrine lights a candle, gazes at the can flame as the match burns down to his fingers, unnoticed. 11. A framed photo of Qohen's Wife and Son walking hand i hand through a field of wildflowers. The photo comes to life, and Wife and Son look out, startled and saddened. 12. Qohen stares at the photo, eyes moistening. He turns and walks out of the alcove to his computer, raising his to the crucifix. Mounted where Jesus' head should be, a MANCAM trains its lens on him, the lens morphing into... 13. The Black Hole... A phone RINGS... fades.

Qohen at his computer, the ManCam trained on him.  24. Qohen's monitor: DR. SHRINK-ROM, 50s, an interactive CD-R therapist. Warm and caring, she sits in a great leather chair, notebook in hand, pen poised.
You seem tense, Qohen. Perhaps you'd like to start over. Let's return to the subject of your fears.
We fear... (deep breath) Nothing.
Go on.
We're afraid we can't.
Of course you can. Let's explore this contradiction. You say you fear nothing, but in previous sessions... A notebook window pops up next to Dr. Shrink-ROM, showing bulleted list she reads from.

...you've reported fear of death, fear of life, fear of open spaces, fear of closed spaces, fear of people, fear of missing a certain phone call, fear of -- Qohen moves his cursor to close the notebook window.
We fear many things, but ultimately we fear nothing more than anything.
Noted. Please go on.
In what manner, Doctor?
Are you trying to be difficult?
Not at all... It seems we're capable of being difficult without trying.
Perhaps you'd like to start over. We've spoken of your fears. Would you care to discuss your joys?  25.
At present, we can think of very little that brings us joy.
(gently) Your wife and son were a source of joy. Weren't they, Qohen? Qohen's eyes cloud.
Why don't you ever talk about them?
What good is joy when it doesn't last? We haven't felt joy in years.
Tell me what you're feeling, Qohen.
We feel... nothing.

You're a tough nut to crack, Qohen... and of course I don't mean "nut" in the pejorative sense... Perhaps you'd like to start over. Let's return to -- The phone RINGS, interrupting. Qohen looks at it with a mixture of hope and despair. He picks it up.
Hello?
Hello... Qohen Leth... Your next installment of data is due for upload in one hour. If the target timetable is attainable, press one. If not -- Qohen presses 2, interrupting the voice.
Please enter estimated number of minutes needed for target overrun. Qohen hesitates, considering, then presses 1-2-0.
A moment, please... ManCom will allow 70 minutes. Goodbye... Qohen Leth. QOHEN . That's not enough time!  26. The line has gone dead. Qohen hangs up.
Perhaps you should get back to work.
What difference does it make? We'll never finish. ManCom sends new downloads before we've finished with the old ones. We've never worked with data like this. It refuses to stay crunched!
Deep breaths, Qohen, deep breaths... Qohen stares up at the crucifix. ManCam's red light shine
All we want is our call...

Yes... Your call... Let's continue our discussion next session. I find your feelings fascinating and look forward -- Qohen clicks on exit, and Dr. Shrink-ROM vanishes. He types a command, and a menu bar reads: ZERO THEOREM PROJECT. A stream of signs and symbols scroll. With a pained expression he goes to work.
Qohen at his computer, feverishly typing. A STORM rages outside, and his driven eyes are lit by LIGHTNING FLASHES He stops typing, freezing the scrolling signs and symbols
This can't be right... Qohen types a command, and the entities begin scrolling i reverse. He slows the stream of symbols, stops.

Nothing adds up... He resumes his typing, the symbols scrolling faster and faster as he works himself into a frenzied pace. Suddenly, LIGHTNING FLASHES and the PHONE RINGS. With a cry of pain, Qohen snatches up the receiver.  27.
